title: TraMOOC: Large-scale Crowdsourcing Activities for Machine Translation and Translation Evaluation

author: Valia Kordoni, Department of English and American Studies, Humboldt University of Berlin

segmentation: OK hello everybody, my name is Valia Cardoni.

I'm a professor of computational linguistics at Humboldt University in Berlin, and I'm going to talk in the next 10 minutes about a Horizon 2020 machine translation project from the 1st generation of the projects.
That's mean that means it started immediately after age 2020, started in 2015 at the beginning and.
Finished few months ago.
The reason I'm here is not to talk to you about either open online courses or.
Machine translation, although it's extremely interesting, I'm here because try MC tent out.
Tomb involve the biggest crowd sourcing activity that they U has financed today.
Actually the only crowd sourcing activity that they you has financed to date with 85,000 euro only for crowd sourcing in the framework of trim Oak.
Let me.
Present the project.
Do you?
So I said that this was a first generation language technology or Horizon 2020 project.
Our AIM intra MC was basically to make monolingual educational material available to speakers of other languages.
Remark was financed in the framework of the first call for Language Technology in the 2020.
For the ones of you who have tried or had projects in this there were three projects.
Ramaco was one of them financed.
Um, then main theme.
There was the crack in the language body that was the theme of the European Union, so the project results are showcased and test it on the open HPI platform.
The Hassle Plattner Institute platform and the videolectures.net Digital Video Lecture Library, an all the core of the services are open source.
They are available via our web page.
That remote web page you can Google it.

Finally we did translate English to 9 European EU languages and two brick languages.
Russian and Croatian, the nine European EU languages.
I'm sorry you languages, you can see it was German, Italian, Portuguese.
Dutch Bulgarian, Greek, Polish, Czech and Croatian.
Um, we had very many novel.
This introductory book was evaluated for funding with 14.5 out of 15 points and we had we were area research and innovation action, so we focused on.
Machine translation, but, um, expanding machine translation with novel evaluation schemata.
I also with topic identification, sentiment analysis and crowdsourcing, was playing a key tenant out to play a key role in all this.
Why did we choose Moocs?
When they you was discussing the.
Main motor for Lt for language technology.
In 2020, the cracking the language barrier.
Everybody was thinking Commerce.
And I was thinking I'm not interested because there are companies who can do this.
The translation of commercial science, if one wants to, you know, buy something from Poland, Russia, Greece when sitting somewhere in Berlin.
And I thought to myself, are much more interested into Moocs.
Massive open online courses.
The reason was that at that time I was reading on how much mooks were expanding, how many more universities were offering them?
And I said that we are focusing on educate.
Optional.
Our content, so obviously I'm not going to tell you everything about remote, but I'm what I want you to focus on this.
This is the project structure I want you to focus upstairs where it says machine translation and then explicit translation evaluation and implicit translation evaluation.
All of these happened basically through them, then bullet, which was pointing to data collection and infrastructure exploration and adaptation.
And bootstrapping all of these was where crowdsourcing resided intra MC.
Just for history we were those I was coordinating at humble.
Then we had the Dublin City University, the deluxe media, the University of Edinburgh Ionian University in Greece, the Radboud University in the deal book University in the Netherlands here.
Yes, Anna company responsible for our PR and Technical Support in Patras in Greece and knowledge for all.
Um, with the base in London and we were using the hassle Plattner MC.
That form, um, what is interesting for you is that we decided to crowdsourced translations into MC.
Um, we wanted to do that becausw this was a natural thing to do and we wanted to feel a bit like Google for some time in our lives.
Yeah, I mean, they're crowdsourcing translation themselves anyway, so we we in the effort to do that, we searched and researched and ranked multiple platforms, which I would never dare to put.
On a single slide, because I don't want to put companies on the slide and judge them.
What I will say is that for purple the purposes of a.
3 million euro project with almost 100,000 euro set for crowdsourcing for for institutes based in Europe.
The best solution was crowd flower in the end.

It was ranked in our research which lasted for months with it and a market search for four months for our purposes was ranked second best after the Amazon Mechanical Turk and the reason was that the reason we rejected Mechanical Turk was that it is inflexible for people sitting in Europe.
You can't do anything if you don't have a V 18 number in the US, you simply cannot use Mechanical Turk ham in Europe.
Soap.
We didn't bother any longer, so Crowdflower on, on the other hand, was also having a few features which were very, very interesting.
For our purposes, we could configure it ourselves.
We could.
Sort of play with the with its infrastructure in a manner which was making sense for our engineers.

It has densely populated crowd channels and so the valuation in the ranking process they undergo with interesting and can contribute to quality control has convenient payment options and nobody knew how to do a contract between a European institution like Humboldt.
And somebody sitting on the West Coast, we found out in between the you had no clue Ann.
And of course Crowdflower has, as we saw when we were testing it.
High deception in popularity level for the Microtasking field.
So for us it was crowd.
With what we crowdsourced was, translation was translation evaluation and also sentiment and topic annotation.

With that sentiment, analysis on MC data basically pertaining to four data students taking a course, getting material going through the 789 weeks of the course talking to each other on the floor of how the courses.

Whether it's good or bad or how, then the presentations are, and so on and so forth, and then the topic annotation we needed to do because we need we we had to deal with my very many genres of open online.
In courses.
So we did parallel translation of English segments.
Today 11 languages were talking about 11 million segments, so each language pair had 1 million segments crowdsourced.

The monks we got from diversity.

This is a MC company based in Berlin Kucera, whom we couldn't include in the consortium, but we had in our extended Advisory Board and we cooperated very close to them, and various corpora here is security corpus.
It's corpus from somewhere in the Emirates with parallel data so.
We were, um, listening to the presentation before about crowdsourcing we started with.
And basically configuring a try configuring them and the crowd sourcing platform.
So we had trials internal try and trials.
We did various experiments with languages.
Here I have for Greek and for Dutch we were looking at design refinements and setting calibrations for timeframe allocations to completing a job for number of segments per job.
Para notate or we were.
And we run a lot before opening the translations to the public.
We did quality control refinements very many test questions, type of test questions, what we would show the crowd source is what we will not show the crowds.
Motives in the translation evaluation.
We included three sub activities.
We were looking at adequacy and fluency.
We were looking at error type markup and post editing.
We were also looking at ranking of translation.
And we also had had an activity for sentiment and topic and.
Annotation.
Now, in order to reach the stage where we opened the translations to the crowd.
Sources we had to do a lot to prepare the data, so we process the data by looking at organizations sent to send this segmentation through case in capital non capital letters.
We wanted to make sure that we have proper sentence alignment that URLs are marked marked properly.
We had.
Babe, we did very many procedures in order to convert various forms of text into plain text like PDFs into plain texts.
And basically we were.
They generally performed using the pipeline of available sentence splitters.
Aligners, data source, Taylor Python And Shell script.
We had a lot along period of pre processing the data that we would make.
We would give to the crowds.
Sourcers um there was a need for a uniform in domain test set throughout the project, so we started by extracting 80,000 words from the MC materials that Iversity and Deluxe made available to us.
We manually translate it in order to create a gold standard into Greek, Italian and Portuguese from students.
We had students and professional translators doing that.
We included three of these.
3 Languages, Greek, Italian and Portuguese into even the first prototype of machine translation, and we opened the rest of the translation for the remaining eight language pairs to the crowd source.
Tips?
For the data collection that we were doing, in order to give to the crowd source and sources, we had challenges like challenging crawling.
Sometimes we had complicated structures for them of the web resources.
Sometimes we had to stop automatic rolling for lots.
For large scale data we had challenging data extraction and alignment.
Most material in PDF sometimes possible misalignments during the conversion into possible.
A text we had always to keep in mind, to remain faithful to the representatives representativeness of the material we were given to the crowd sources.
So we needed a balance between slides, notes, assignment.
These things were rarely translated.
We needed to see what we were doing.
We had very many Copyright issues.
The data because you talked a lot about ethics and I will close here without a slide in the middle of the of the process of Pramukh they you came back to us and they said oh you deal with data.
I said yes you have financed this.
Dealing with data said oh, we need ethics agreement.
I think we said OK, do you have such agreement?
We can give to the crowd.
Source said no, you're doing them.
We said haha, and so that was really the procedure that was really.
It is documented in written and so in the middle of the project I had to pull and there was no parallel.
There was no bloody parallel, so I had to pull a team of legal experts in five countries because we had also different laws.
So there was a professor from the University of the Saloniki their subtle University of the Saloniki leading professor glasses.
He helped us a lot.
He's an expert on on the European level of ethics on data exchange and then we had the experts in Germany, the Netherlands, in.
Um in in in Ireland also.
And finally we came up with an agreement that was acceptable.
According to our national regulations from the different countries participating.
They young and of course the crowd flower because this agreement had to go over Crowdflower because this way this was a platform recruiting the crowd sources.
It was fun.
I learned a lot of things that I don't personally need.
I'm doing an NLP AI and machine translation so.
It is true that we are at the stage now in the European Union level that as usual we are doing the work from bottom to give it ready to the top, which is the European Union.
An I Fortunately didn't have to deal with.
GDP R yeah it was before that.
It was complicated enough.
So I believe that as one of the people said in.
In.
In, in, in the previous session, it has its case per case, so you have to see what what you need in in the cost initiative in this cost initiative and just don't take a solutions off the shelf.
There are none.
Or if they are, put them up on the web that other people can profit.
Thank you very much.
Thank you.
